<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/zoom-fire-security-privacy-lapses?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Zoom Races to Catch Up With Itself
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Zoom laptop" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NDQvem9vbV9sYXB0b3AuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the coronavirus pandemic era, videoconferencing company Zoom has quickly zum from successful enterprise firm →  essential utility → new face of Big Tech's privacy and security challenges. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To break that journey down...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Part 1: </strong>Founded in 2011, Zoom <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-04-09/zoom-goes-from-conferencing-app-to-the-pandemic-s-social-network?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">met rising demand</a> for workplace video calls that 1) didn't freeze every 10 minutes and 2) launched quickly. It did that well—when Zoom went public last April, shares popped 72% in an otherwise meh year for IPOs. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Part 2: </strong>As social distancing became the norm over the past month, Zoom's usage has exploded about 20x since December. And it's not just the numbers—the types of users have changed as well; schools, religious institutions, and friends are using it to connect.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Part 3: </strong>With all that traffic, Zoom's flaws have been exposed. A <a href="https://theintercept.com/2020/03/31/zoom-meeting-encryption/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report from The Intercept</a> showed the service did not have end-to-end encryption, despite marketing itself to that effect. Others found security holes that could allow hackers to plant malware. And then there are the trolls—people who "Zoombomb" calls by sneaking in and displaying inappropriate content like pornography. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Senate's sergeant at arms reportedly warned the chamber's members not to use the service. Many private sector firms, like Google and SpaceX, have banned employees from using it.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Zoom has patched many of those security issues and apologized for the encryption debacle. Last week, it instituted a 90-day pause on other initiatives to devote engineering resources exclusively to privacy and security.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">~Zoom~ out: </strong>Achilles needed his heel to become Greece's greatest warrior and Zoom needed a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/zoom-privacy-lessons.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">super-simple user experience</a> to become popular. It's this ease of use—like the ability to join calls with one click—that made Zoom vulnerable to attacks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, it wasn't prepared for the influx of non-enterprise users. Zoom typically leaves some security practices up to customers, since in normal circumstances they're businesses. But it's less reasonable to ask teachers or your aunt who's three Chardonnays deep to configure their own security settings.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F09%2Fzoom-fire-security-privacy-lapses" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+last+few+months+have+been+a+real+journey+for+the+videoconferencing+company+&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/zoom-fire-security-privacy-lapses&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86574d1eb82.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F09%2Fzoom-fire-security-privacy-lapses&title=Zoom+Under+Fire+for+Security%2C+Privacy+Lapses+&source=www.morningbrew.com&summary=The+last+few+months+have+been+a+real+journey+for+the+videoconferencing+company+" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/us-labor-market-sheds-17m-jobs-3-weeks?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Cursed Chart Returns
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Unemployment claims chart" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NDMvdW5lbXBsb3ltZW50X2NsYWltc19jaGFydC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://www.vox.com/2020/4/9/21213449/unemployment-initial-claims-us-april-4" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Vox</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last week, 6.6 million U.S. workers <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/04/09/830216099/6-6-million-more-file-for-unemployment-as-coronavirus-keeps-economy-shut?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">filed for unemployment</a>, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Feeling déjà vu? The agency also <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/02/unemployment-claims-near-10m-last-two-weeks-march?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">also reported</a> 6.6 million first-time claims the last full week of March, a staggering number it's since revised up to 6.9 million. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We had to break out the calculator to tackle these numbers. In a three-week span, nearly 17 million workers (about 10% of the U.S. workforce) filed for unemployment. Pennsylvania and California accounted for ~20% of claims. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>To handle the influx, New York has 1,000 people processing unemployment applications. It's also </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/illinois-new-york-residents-among-first-to-see-bigger-virus-unemployment-payments-11586362632?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fronting the money</a></span><span> for $600 payments individuals can claim under the federal relief package on top of regular unemployment checks.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Experts don't know how far up the mountain we are, but they're pretty sure the summit is a ways off. Moody's projects 45 million jobs are at risk because of this pandemic.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>A couple more weeks of numbers like this and the U.S. economy will wipe out the 24.8 million jobs gained from February 2010 to February 2020. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/fed-unleashes-another-round-stimulus-measures?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
He Is Not Throwing Away His Shot
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jerome Powell testifying before Congress" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MC9qZXJvbWVfcG93ZWxsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>U.S. Federal Reserve</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If Jerome Powell isn't the subject of a Lin-Manuel Miranda musical when Broadway returns, we give up. The Fed chair unleashed $2.3 trillion in <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-fed-mainstreet/fed-rolls-out-2-3-trillion-to-backstop-main-street-local-governments-idUSKCN21R1WY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">additional stimulus juice</a> to try to save the U.S. economy from its worst possible fate. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We keep saying these Fed measures are bigger than the last, but...this one may actually be. Yesterday's infusion targets "Main Street" with loans to households, small and mid-sized businesses, and cash-strapped state and local governments. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Fed </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-09/fed-unleashes-fresh-steps-for-as-much-as-2-3-trillion-in-aid?srnd=premium&sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised some eyebrows</a></span><span> by saying it'll directly buy municipal debt and fund the purchases of some high-yield bonds—an unusual move.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But these are "very unusual circumstances," Powell said on a webcast carried by the Brookings Institution. "The Fed's role is to provide as much relief and stability as we can" during this time. Powell also acknowledged that the Fed only has "lending powers, not spending powers." It needs to get paid back.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The Fed is using every tool imaginable—slashing interest rates, ensuring liquidity in credit markets, and now directly helping small businesses—to, in Powell's words, make people "whole." </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GROCERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/walmarts-grocery-app-surges-past-amazon?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Walmart = Mr. Freeze, Amazon = Dude in Cargo Shorts
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A Mr. Freeze race at a baseball game " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=376 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/541/freeze_race.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A Mr. Freeze race at a baseball game " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/541/freeze_race.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We promised we wouldn't use this GIF in the newsletter unless it was absolutely necessary.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That moment has arrived. A new report from <a href="https://www.appannie.com/en/insights/market-data/walmart-grocery-takes-1-spot-in-shopping-app-downloads/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">App Annie</a> shows that Walmart Grocery came from wayyyy behind to snag the No. 1 downloaded shopping app in the U.S. last week, topping Amazon by 20%. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Walmart Grocery's average daily downloads were up 460% over January, as of April 5. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NDAvd2FsbWFydF92c19hbWF6b25fZGVsaXZlcnkucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>App Annie</em> </small></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><strong style="color:#000">An interesting wrinkle:</strong> Pre COVID-19, Walmart had planned to fold Grocery into its flagship mobile app and website. The company <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/09/walmart-grocery-app-sees-record-downloads-amid-covid-19-surpasses-amazon-by-20/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told TechCrunch</a> it hasn't changed its thinking despite the current popularity of the app. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To everyone at the <a href="https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">National Suicide Prevention Lifeline</a>, <a href="https://www.crisistextline.org/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Crisis Text Line</a>, and many more: We at Morning Brew are grateful for the work you do always, but especially now.</p>

Don’t ask for an encore, because U.S. markets are closed today for Good Friday.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOil: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSaudi Arabia and Russia \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/opec-agrees-deep-oil-output-151440841.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eagreed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to production cuts to revive the sputtering oil market. OPEC+ will seek additional cuts from Group of 20 energy ministers, who meet today.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nTECH \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/zoom-fire-security-privacy-lapses?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nZoom Races to Catch Up With Itself\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Zoom laptop\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NDQvem9vbV9sYXB0b3AuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the coronavirus pandemic era, videoconferencing company Zoom has quickly zum from successful enterprise firm →  essential utility → new face of Big Tech's privacy and security challenges. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo break that journey down...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePart 1: \u003c/strong\u003eFounded in 2011, Zoom \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-04-09/zoom-goes-from-conferencing-app-to-the-pandemic-s-social-network?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emet rising demand\u003c/a\u003e for workplace video calls that 1) didn't freeze every 10 minutes and 2) launched quickly. It did that well—when Zoom went public last April, shares popped 72% in an otherwise meh year for IPOs. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePart 2: \u003c/strong\u003eAs social distancing became the norm over the past month, Zoom's usage has exploded about 20x since December. And it's not just the numbers—the types of users have changed as well; schools, religious institutions, and friends are using it to connect.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePart 3: \u003c/strong\u003eWith all that traffic, Zoom's flaws have been exposed. A \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2020/03/31/zoom-meeting-encryption/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport from The Intercept\u003c/a\u003e showed the service did not have end-to-end encryption, despite marketing itself to that effect. Others found security holes that could allow hackers to plant malware. And then there are the trolls—people who \"Zoombomb\" calls by sneaking in and displaying inappropriate content like pornography. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Senate's sergeant at arms reportedly warned the chamber's members not to use the service. Many private sector firms, like Google and SpaceX, have banned employees from using it.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eZoom has patched many of those security issues and apologized for the encryption debacle. Last week, it instituted a 90-day pause on other initiatives to devote engineering resources exclusively to privacy and security.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e~Zoom~ out: \u003c/strong\u003eAchilles needed his heel to become Greece's greatest warrior and Zoom needed a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/article/zoom-privacy-lessons.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuper-simple user experience\u003c/a\u003e to become popular. It's this ease of use—like the ability to join calls with one click—that made Zoom vulnerable to attacks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, it wasn't prepared for the influx of non-enterprise users. Zoom typically leaves some security practices up to customers, since in normal circumstances they're businesses. But it's less reasonable to ask teachers or your aunt who's three Chardonnays deep to configure their own security settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast week, 6.6 million U.S. workers \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/04/09/830216099/6-6-million-more-file-for-unemployment-as-coronavirus-keeps-economy-shut?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efiled for unemployment\u003c/a\u003e, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Feeling déjà vu? The agency also \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/02/unemployment-claims-near-10m-last-two-weeks-march?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealso reported\u003c/a\u003e 6.6 million first-time claims the last full week of March, a staggering number it's since revised up to 6.9 million. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe had to break out the calculator to tackle these numbers. In a three-week span, nearly 17 million workers (about 10% of the U.S. workforce) filed for unemployment. Pennsylvania and California accounted for ~20% of claims. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eTo handle the influx, New York has 1,000 people processing unemployment applications. It's also \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/illinois-new-york-residents-among-first-to-see-bigger-virus-unemployment-payments-11586362632?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efronting the money\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for $600 payments individuals can claim under the federal relief package on top of regular unemployment checks.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eExperts don't know how far up the mountain we are, but they're pretty sure the summit is a ways off. Moody's projects 45 million jobs are at risk because of this pandemic.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eA couple more weeks of numbers like this and the U.S. economy will wipe out the 24.8 million jobs gained from February 2010 to February collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf Jerome Powell isn't the subject of a Lin-Manuel Miranda musical when Broadway returns, we give up. The Fed chair unleashed $2.3 trillion in \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-fed-mainstreet/fed-rolls-out-2-3-trillion-to-backstop-main-street-local-governments-idUSKCN21R1WY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadditional stimulus juice\u003c/a\u003e to try to save the U.S. economy from its worst possible fate. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe keep saying these Fed measures are bigger than the last, but...this one may actually be. Yesterday's infusion targets \"Main Street\" with loans to households, small and mid-sized businesses, and cash-strapped state and local governments. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Fed \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-09/fed-unleashes-fresh-steps-for-as-much-as-2-3-trillion-in-aid?srnd=premium\u0026sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised some eyebrows\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e by saying it'll directly buy municipal debt and fund the purchases of some high-yield bonds—an unusual move.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut these are \"very unusual circumstances,\" Powell said on a webcast carried by the Brookings Institution. \"The Fed's role is to provide as much relief and stability as we can\" during this time. Powell also acknowledged that the Fed only has \"lending powers, not spending powers.\" It needs to get paid back.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Fed is using every tool imaginable—slashing interest rates, ensuring liquidity in credit markets, and now directly helping small businesses—to, in Powell's words, make people \"whole.\" \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable A new report from \u003ca href=\"https://www.appannie.com/en/insights/market-data/walmart-grocery-takes-1-spot-in-shopping-app-downloads/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eApp Annie\u003c/a\u003e shows that Walmart Grocery came from wayyyy behind to snag the No. 1 downloaded shopping app in the U.S. last week, topping Amazon by 20%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWalmart Grocery's average daily downloads were up 460% over January, as of April 5. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NDAvd2FsbWFydF92c19hbWF6b25fZGVsaXZlcnkucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"640\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;\" alt=\"\" data-reactroot=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e \u003cem\u003eApp Annie\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/small\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAn interesting wrinkle:\u003c/strong\u003e Pre COVID-19, Walmart had planned to fold Grocery into its flagship mobile app and website.
